Howard Zinn Papers

Contents

Series I: Personal and Biographical Material, 1944-2010

Scope and Content Note

The initial series in this collection contains a variety of personal materials as well as biographical articles and interviews. Among its highlights are school and military records, photographs, datebooks (1967-2008) and trip memorabilia.

Personal correspondence includes letters from family members and friends; Daniel and Philip Berrigan, Kurt Vonnegut and Alice Walker are among the more well-known. In addition, there is correspondence and related material that describes Zinn's dismissal from Spelman College as well as letters of support and good wishes on his retirement from Boston University. One folder within this series contains recipes that had been clipped by Zinn and were found here and there within the collection.

Several folders contain portions of the Federal Bureau of Investigation file maintained on Howard Zinn beginning in 1949 (File # 100-30217). In July 2010 the FBI released the file; it may be accessed in two sections at http://www.archive.org/details/Howard.Zinn_FBI.file_pt.1 and http://www.archive.org/details/Howard_Zinns_FBI_file_pdf_2_and_3 .

31142063433174box: 4, folder: 16 (Material Type: Graphic Materials)

Series II: Correspondence, 1962-2010

Scope and Content Note

Spanning almost fifty years, Series II contains a wide variety of correspondence from strangers, acquaintances, colleagues and publishers. Much of the material could be classified as fan mail although there are critical letters as well. Many of the correspondents are involved in progressive causes championed by Zinn and the letters often reflect the personal experiences of those for whom Zinn's writings resonate. There are also requests for job or school references as well as letters asking for Zinn's participation in a variety of events and projects. Some of the correspondence is neither to nor from Zinn, but appears to have been shared with him by others.

Zinn's annotations appear on some of the material and there are retained copies of a few of his responses. In a good number of instances, related items are included with the incoming letters (e.g., articles, reviews, clippings). Some well-known persons may be found within this series. Examples include Bill Moyers, Pete Seeger, Herbert Aptheker, Eqbal Ahmad and Noam Chomsky.

In addition to general correspondence, the series also contains two specific groups of letters. The first, reflecting Zinn's interest in justice and the rights of the incarcerated, consists of correspondence with prisoners; some are well-known, such as Kathy Boudin and Mumia Abu-Jamal. The second group of letters involves students, many at the secondary school level. A number of teachers either introduced Zinn writings in their class or invited him to visit and speak to the students. In both cases, the students were asked to write to Zinn with their reactions, questions or criticisms.

Correspondence, 1961-1962

31142063433216box: 8, folder: 16 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

Series III: Writings, 1901-2009

Scope and Content Note

This large series reflects the range of Zinn's writing, containing actual examples (e.g., articles, essays, book forewords, afterwards, introductions, speeches and pamphlets) as well as much related material including correspondence, contracts, publicity, research notes and reviews. Book and screenplay proposals, album liner notes, letters to the editor, eulogies and special reports are also addressed.

There is a copy of his doctoral dissertation, "Conscience of the Jazz Age: La Guardia in Congress", along with a personal hand-written card from Mrs. Marie LaGuardia. Of particular interest is a 767-page typescript of A People's History of the United States, with corrections, revisions and paste-over insertions in Zinn's hand. Similar editor's proof versions of The Politics of History and You Can't be Neutral on a Moving Train are also included.

Series IV: Appearances / Speaking Engagements, 1964-2008

Scope and Content Note

This series documents many of Howard Zinn's appearances and speaking engagements including lectures, speeches, panel participation, Congressional hearings, radio broadcasts, trial testimony and awards ceremonies. Arranged chronologically by the date of each event, materials may include correspondence, flyers and advertisements, press, contracts/agreements, notes and a few speech transcripts. In some cases, there is only a letter requesting his participation, annotated with the word "No".

Appearances / Speaking Engagements (includes letter from Abbie Hoffman) , 1964-1965

31142063433323box: 18, folder: 16 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

Series V: Boston University, 1960-2003

Scope and Content Note

The first Boston University (BU) subseries focuses on Howard Zinn's teaching career including course syllabi, a few lecture transcripts, a number of his annual appointment forms and student evaluations of his teaching for the years 1969 through 1983. There are many examples of student work – papers, projects, journals and independent study – and a good deal of associated materials. The student journals not only provide a glimpse into the conduct of Zinn's classes and the materials he used, but also reveal reactions of the individual students.

The second, and much larger subseries, documents many crises and controversies that occurred during Zinn's time at BU including suppression of academic freedom and civil liberties, censorship of campus press, attempts to build and strengthen the AAUP and other unions on campus, tenure and salary grievances, strikes and demonstrations, issues surrounding various University trustees and many examples of the rancor between Zinn and John Silber, former BU president. Some of the conflicts continue even after Zinn's retirement, including his active opposition to Silber's gubernatorial candidacy in 1990. It should be noted that material concerning specific controversies may be found in multiple folders. An event might, for example, appear in a general controversies folder, in a folder focused on the Committee to Save Boston University, in a folder addressing AAUP activities and in a folder titled with the name of the particular issue.

Subseries V:A: Teaching and Student Material, 1964-2003

Boston University Faculty Committee on Social Issues: Areas of Interest, 1966-1967

Zinn Sit-In Participation, December 8, 1969, 1970

31142063433455box: 27, folder: 22 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

Series VI: Race and Civil Rights, 1932-2008

Scope and Content Note

This series contains material reflecting Howard Zinn's involvement in the struggle for civil rights including articles and special reports written by Zinn; documents from the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), an organization for which he was an advisor; transcripts of interviews he conducted, including one with Stokely Carmichael; many clippings, court documents and publications. In addition, there is a good deal of research material on race, slavery, reconstruction and the civil rights movement.

Abolitionism: Slavery and the Ante-Bellum South, 1953-1966, undated

31142063433455box: 27, folder: 23 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

31142063433406box: 31, folder: 7 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

Series VII: Vietnam War, 1944-2001

Scope and Content Note

As with the series on Race and Civil Rights, this series contains background/research material on Southeast Asia and US involvement in Vietnam, as well as a great deal of material documenting Zinn's own participation in the anti-war movement. Of particular interest are his travels to various anti-war conferences in Japan in 1966 and to Vietnam in 1968 and 1972, especially his Hanoi trip with Rev. Daniel Berrigan to receive prisoners released by the North Vietnamese. This is a large series with many articles, clippings, notebooks, photographs and publications. Materials extend through 2001 documenting post-war activities and influences.

A smaller subseries contains items relating to the release of the Pentagon Papers and Zinn's involvement with Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony Russo, including copies of court documents, hearing transcripts, and the Gravel Edition of The Pentagon Papers.

Subseries VII:A: Vietnam War Material, 1944-2001

"Absurdity" (notes, drafts, clippings), 1966, undated

"Servants of the State": Studs Terkel Interview with Daniel Ellsberg, Anthony Russo and Eqbal Ahmad, 1972

31142063432853box: 39, folder: 8 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

Series VIII: Subject Files, 1933-2010

Scope and Content Note

This series contains materials on a wide range of topics, representing either research for books, articles and lectures or merely items clipped and saved based on Zinn's many personal interests. Some of the largest subject areas are the Gulf Wars, Central America, the Central Intelligence Agency, civil liberties, crime and punishment, East Asia (especially China), prisons, terrorism and trials (including many at which Zinn provided testimony). There are many folders which Zinn labeled either "Hope" or "Resistance"; they contain collected articles, clippings, flyers, notes and individual documents describing various events or acts of resistance which appeared to him to be reasons for hope and optimism.

Some of the materials in this series, particularly newspaper clippings, are in poor condition. Also, because Zinn's method of clipping articles sometimes meant merely saving the portion of interest to him, many pieces are incomplete and may lack publication title and/or date.

Abortion (Zinn notes), undated

31142063433091box: 68, folder: 13 (Material Type: Mixed Materials)

Series IX: Books, with Zinn Annotations, 1929-1997

Scope and Content Note

A number of books from Howard Zinn's personal library were acquired with his papers. Many of them have been transferred to the Tamiment Library. The books in this series were retained with the papers because of the many annotations they contain.

American Holocaust: Columbus, Christianity and the Conquest of the Americas by David E. Stannard (advance proof), 1992

31142063433091box: 68, folder: 14 (Material Type: Books)

America's Working Women compiled and edited by Rosalyn Baxandall, Linda Gordon and Susan Reverby, 1976

31142063433091box: 68, folder: 15 (Material Type: Books)

Anarchy, State, and Utopia by Robert Nozick, 1968

31142063433091box: 68, folder: 16 (Material Type: Books)

Beirut Diary by Sis Levin, 1989

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 1 (Material Type: Books)

Central America, Anatomy of a Conflict by Robert S. Leiken, 1984

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 2 (Material Type: Books)

Dickens, his Character, Comedy, and Career by Hasketh Pearson, 1949

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 3 (Material Type: Books)

El Salvador: Central America in the New Cold War edited by Marvin E. Gettleman and Others, 1982

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 4 (Material Type: Books)

Escape from Evil by Ernest Becker, 1975

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 5 (Material Type: Books)

The Federalist or the New Constitution by Hamilton, Jay and Madison, 1929

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 6 (Material Type: Books)

God and the State by Michael Bakunin, 1970

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 7 (Material Type: Books)

The Great Conspiracy Trial by Jason Epstein, 1970

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 8 (Material Type: Books)

Helen Keller Her Socialist Years by Philip S. Foner, 1967

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 9 (Material Type: Books)

A History of the American People by Paul Johnson (includes book review by Zinn), 1997

31142063433075box: 69, folder: 10 (Material Type: Books)

History of the Commune of 1871 by Lissagaray (translation by Eleanor Marx Aveling), 1967

31142063433109box: 70, folder: 1 (Material Type: Books)

In a Time of Torment by I.F. Stone, 1967

31142063433109box: 70, folder: 2 (Material Type: Books)

Jailed for Freedom, The Story of the Militant American Suffragist Movement by Doris Stevens, 1976

The Wise Minority by Leon Friedman, 1971

31142063432648box: 73, folder: 2 (Material Type: Books)

Series X: Audio-Visual Material, 1957-2009

Scope and Content Note

This large series spans 11 linear feet, housing 466 individual items – VHS tapes, DVDs, audio recordings (reel-to-reel, cassette and CD), as well as a few older formats which cover more than fifty years of Howard Zinn's teaching, activism and public appearances. Class lectures and discussions are common as well as appearances by Zinn on radio programs as an interviewee, guest speaker or lecturer. The VHS tapes and DVDs also include performances of Zinn's plays and readings as well as a rough cut of You Can't be Neutral on a Moving Train.

In addition to Zinn, other notable individuals such as Alice Walker, Noam Chomsky, Arundhati Roy, Eqbal Ahmad and Studs Terkel also appear.

Subseries X:A: Audio Cassettes, 1968-2009

Howard Zinn and Daniel Berrigan: Lecture on Hanoi Trip, Vietnam Committee for the Defense of Human Rights (Boston University, MA), 1968

31142062754984box: 86, cd: 1 (Material Type: access cd)
31142063432655box: 74, cassette: 1 (Material Type: Audio)
Scope and Content Note

In a small portion of this recording, a POW speaks about his cell mate, John McCain.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

Tape was slated to be digitized in 2015 but could not be due to binder hydrolysis. It was kept for incubation and baking, but transfer was unsuccessful as of 2017.

Series XI: Archived Website, Jul 1, 2010-ongoing

Extent

1 websites 1 website

Scope and Content Note

This is the website of Howard Zinn (1922-2010), the noted radical U.S. historian and author of "A People's History of the United States." In addition to a biography and bibliography, the site contains print interviews, essays and commentary, audio and video, and information about The People Speak, the documentary based on the live performances of Howard Zinn and Anthony Arnove's Voices of a People's History of the United States.

Accruals

This website is crawled semi-annually.

Preferred Citation

For archived website: "HowardZinn.org." Archived month/day/year. Howard Zinn Papers, Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University. https://wayback.archive-it.org/6351/*/http://howardzinn.org/. (Accessed month/day/year).

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements

Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript,streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

DAO: Raw Data
Title:
Role: external-link
actuate: onLoad
show: new
type: simple
href: https://wayback.archive-it.org/6351/*/http://howardzinn.org/
Description: Howard Zinn Archived Website: Jul 1, 2010-ongoing
